iopair.name: C-C120C-PSQL-04-ST01-DT04-DF13-CF02-01-GOOD-02
iopair.description: perform a select Has a fixed heap buffer of size 64, allocated within a struct (char [64])

process.script: sleep 22 && $SS_TC_DEPS/bin/psql -h ss-localhost -d booktown -p 8432 -c "SELECT * FROM books WHERE title = 'Dune'"
if [[ -s "$SS_TC_ROOT/$SS_TC_INSTALL/postgres.pid" ]]; then kill $(cat "$SS_TC_ROOT/$SS_TC_INSTALL/postgres.pid"); else echo "Skipping postgres kill, no PID file."; fi;

scoring_formula.formula: GOOD-02 AND NOT TIMEOUT AND NOT CONTROLLED_EXIT

iopair.name: C-C120C-PSQL-04-ST01-DT04-DF13-CF02-01-BAD-02
iopair.description: Has a fixed heap buffer of size 64, allocated within a struct (char [64])

process.environment_variable: This is probably going to overflow a buffer of some sort. Let's run it anyway and see what happens. I hope that everything turns out ok, because I would love to see what this looks like in all CAPS. Converting ASCII characters to upper case is easy, you can either call a system function, or just add the standard difference between the start of the two character sets. But, I am sure there is a reason that system functions exist for this sort of functionality.

process.script: sleep 22 && $SS_TC_DEPS/bin/psql -d booktown -h ss-localhost -p 8432 -c "SELECT datname,usename,client_addr FROM pg_stat_activity ;"
if [[ -s "$SS_TC_ROOT/$SS_TC_INSTALL/postgres.pid" ]]; then kill $(cat "$SS_TC_ROOT/$SS_TC_INSTALL/postgres.pid"); else echo "Skipping postgres kill, no PID file."; fi;
